recreate: To give fresh life to; to reanimate; to revive; especially, torefresh after wearying toil or anxiety; to relieve; to cheer; todivert; to amuse; to gratify.Painters, when they work on white grounds, place before them colorsmixed with blue and green, to recreate their eyes, white wearying . .. the sight more than any. Dryden.St. John, who recreated himself with sporting with a tame partridge.Jer. Taylor.These ripe fruits recreate the nostrils with their aromatic scent.Dr. H. More.
reak: A rush. [Obs.] "Feeds on reaks and reeds." Drant.
rumbler: One who, or that which, rumbles.
reestablishment: The act reëstablishing; the state of being reëstablished.Addison.
realist: One who believes in realism; esp., one who maintains thatgenerals, or the terms used to denote the genera and species ofthings, represent real existences, and are not mere names, asmaintained by the nominalists.
retrievable: That may be retrieved or recovered; admitting of retrieval.-- Re*triev"a*ble*ness, n.-- Re*triev"a*bly, adv.
renard: A fox; -- so called in fables or familiar tales, and in poetry.[Written also reynard.]
ricinelaidic: Pertaining to, or designating, an isomeric modification ofricinoleic acid obtained as a white crystalline solid.
rheumic: Pertaining to, or characterized by, rheum. Rheumic diathesis.See Dartrous diathesis, under Dartrous.
runlet: A little run or stream; a streamlet; a brook.To trace out to its marshy source every runlet that has cast in itstiny pitcherful with the rest. Lowell.
rhetorical: Of or pertaining to rhetoric; according to, or exhibiting,rhetoric; oratorical; as, the rhetorical art; a rhetorical treatise;a rhetorical flourish.They permit him to leave their poetical taste ungratified, providedthat he gratifies their rhetorical sense. M. Arnold.-- Rhe*tor"ic*al*ly, adv.-- Rhe*tor"ic*al*ness, n.
ray grass: A perennial European grass (Lolium perenne); -- called also ryegrass, and red darnel. See Darnel, and Grass. Italian ray, or rye,grass. See Darnel, and Grass.
resale: A sale at second hand, or at retail; also, a second sale.Bacon.
retinoid: Resinlike, or resinform; resembling a resin without being such.
rank: Rankly; stoutly; violently. [Obs.]That rides so rank and bends his lance so fell. Fairfax.
reprehensible: Worthy of reprehension; culpable; censurable; blamable.-- Rep`re*hen"si*ble*ness, n.-- Rep`re*hen"si*bly, adv.
rhino-: A combining form from Greek the nose, as in rhinolith,rhinology.
regard: To look attentively; to consider; to notice. [Obs.] Shak.
reef-band: A piece of canvas sewed across a sail to strengthen it in thepart where the eyelet holes for reefing are made. Totten.
raught: imp. & p. p. of Reach. Shak.
rhabdosphere: A minute sphere composed of rhabdoliths.
rostral: Of or pertaining to the beak or snout of an animal, or the beakof a ship; resembling a rostrum, esp., the rostra at Rome, or theirdecorations.[Monuments] adorned with rostral crowns and naval ornaments. Addison.
readjuster: One who, or that which, readjusts; in some of the States of theUnited States, one who advocates a refunding, and sometimes a partialrepudiation, of the State debt without the consent of the State'screditors.
reestablish: To establish anew; to fix or confirm again; to restore; as, toreëstablish a covenant; to reëstablish health.
reverberation: The act of reverberating; especially, the act of reflectinglight or heat, or reëchoing sound; as, the reverberation of rays froma mirror; the reverberation of rays from a mirror; the reverberationof voices; the reverberation of heat or flame in a furnace.
reflectible: Capable of being reflected, or thrown back; reflexible.
racket-tailed: Having long and spatulate, or racket-shaped, tail feathers.
report: To return or present as the result of an examination orconsideration of any matter officially referred; as, the committeereported the bill witth amendments, or reported a new bill, orreported the results of an inquiry.
rein: To be guided by reins. [R.] Shak.
rider: A problem of more than usual difficulty added to another on anexamination paper.
roccellin: A red dyestuff, used as a substitute for cochineal, archil,etc. It consists of the sodium salt of a complex azo derivative ofnaphtol.
rubican: Colored a prevailing red, bay, or black, with flecks of whiteor gray especially on the flanks; -- said of horses. Smart.
renvoy: To send back. [Obs.] "Not dismissing or renvoying her." Bacon.
renardine: Of or pertaining to Renard, the fox, or the tales in whichRenard is mentioned.
reliant: Having, or characterized by, reliance; confident; trusting.
ribbed: Intercalated with slate; -- said of a seam of coal. Raymond.
recession: The act of receding or withdrawing, as from a place, a claim,or a demand. South.Mercy may rejoice upon the recessions of justice. Jer. Taylor.
ring-tailed: Having the tail crossed by conspicuous bands of color. Ring-tailed cat (Zoöl.), the cacomixle.-- Ring-tailed eagle (Zoöl.), a young golden eagle.
renowme: Renown. [Obs.]The glory and renowme of the ancectors. Robynson (More's Utopia).
rummer: A large and tall glass, or drinking cup. [Obs.] J. Philips.
redskin: A common appellation for a North American Indian; -- so calledfrom the color of the skin. Cooper.
rejourn: To adjourn; to put off. [Obs.] Shak.
rory: Dewy. [R.]And shook his wings with rory May-dew wet. Fairfax.
rescriptive: Pertaining to, or answering the purpose of, a rescript; hence,deciding; settling; determining.
reduction: The act or process of reducing. See Reduce, v. t., 6. and Toreduce an equation, To reduce an expression, under Reduce, v. t.
roughness: The quality or state of being rough.
resorcin: A colorless crystalline substance of the phenol series,obtained by melting certain resins, as galbanum, asafetida, etc.,with caustic potash. It is also produced artificially and used inmaking certain dyestuffs, as phthaleïn, fluoresceïn, and eosin.
remedy: The legal means to recover a right, or to obtain redress for awrong. Civil remedy. See under Civil.-- Remedy of the mint (Coinage), a small allowed deviation from thelegal standard of weight and fineness; -- called also tolerance.
rubefaction: The act or process of making red.
recomforture: The act of recomforting; restoration of comfort. [Obs.] Shak.
recognition: The act of recognizing, or the state of being recognized;acknowledgment; formal avowal; knowledge confessed or avowed; notice.The lives of such saints had, at the time of their yearly memorials,solemn recognition in the church of God. Hooker.
regretful: Full of regret; indulging in regrets; repining.-- Re*gret"ful*ly, adv.
rete: A net or network; a plexus; particularly, a network of bloodvessels or nerves, or a part resembling a network.
rose water: Water tinctured with roses by distillation.
rabatine: A collar or cape. [Obs.]  Sir W. Scott.
refix: To fix again or anew; to establish anew. Fuller.
rehearsal: The act of rehearsing; recital; narration; repetition;specifically, a private recital, performance, or season of practice,in preparation for a public exhibition or exercise. Chaucer.In rehearsal of our Lord's Prayer. Hooker.Here's marvelous convenient place for our rehearsal. Shak.Dress rehearsal (Theater), a private preparatory performance of adrama, opera, etc., in costume.
recapper: A tool used for applying a fresh percussion cap or primer to acartridge shell in reloading it.
resoluble: Admitting of being resolved; resolvable; as, bodies resolubleby fire. Boyle.-- Res"o*lu*ble*ness, n.
rensselaerite: A soft, compact variety of talc,, being an altered pyroxene. Itis often worked in a lathe into inkstands and other articles.
resting: a. & n. from Rest, v. t. & i. Resting spore (Bot.), a spore incertain orders of algæ, which remains quiescent, retaining itsvitality, for long periods of time. C. E. Bessey.
renable: Reasonable; also, loquacious. [Obs.] "Most renable of tongue."Piers Plowman.-- Ren"a*bly, adv. [Obs.] Chaucer.
retrospection: The act, or the faculty, of looking back on things past.
reflection: The transference of an excitement from one nerve fiber toanother by means of the nerve cells, as in reflex action. See Reflexaction, under Reflex. Angle of reflection, the angle which anything,as a ray of light, on leaving a reflecting surface, makes with theperpendicular to the surface.-- Angle of total reflection. (Opt.) Same as Critical angle, underCritical.
rudimentary: Very imperfectly developed; in an early stage of development;embryonic.
rehibition: The returning of a thing purchased to the seller, on the groundof defect or frand.
radiophone: An apparatus for the production of sound by the action ofluminous or thermal rays. It is essentially the same as thephotophone.
ramrod: The rod used in ramming home the charge in a muzzle-loadingfirearm.
reverdure: To cover again with verdure. Ld. Berners.
rapprochement: Act or fact of coming or being drawn near or together;establishment or state of cordial relations.
retractor: One who, or that which, retracts. Specifically:(a) In breech-loading firearms, a device for withdrawing a cartridgeshell from the barrel. (b) (Surg.)
race suicide: The voluntary failure of the members of a race or people tohave a number of children sufficient to keep the birth rate equal tothe death rate.
reference: The process of sending any matter, for inquiry in a cause, to amaster or other officer, in order that he may ascertain facts andreport to the court.
roric: Of or pertaining to dew; resembling dew; dewy. Roric figures(Physics), figures which appear upon a polished surface, as glass,when objects which have been near to, or in contact with, the surfaceare removed and the surface breathed upon; -- called also Moser'simages.
retrousse: Turned up; -- said of a pug nose.
randing: The act or process of making and applying rands for shoes.
rickstand: A flooring or framework on which a rick is made.
responsory: Containing or making answer; answering. Johnson.
red-tape: Pertaining to, or characterized by, official formality. See Redtape, under Red, a.
reliquian: Of or pertaining to a relic or relics; of the nature of arelic. [R.]
redden: To make red or somewhat red; to give a red color to.
riga fir: A species of pine (Pinus sylvestris), and its wood, whichaffords a valuable timber; -- called also Scotch pine, and red oryellow deal. It grows in all parts of Europe, in the Caucasus, and inSiberia.
rococo: A florid style of ornamentation which prevailed in Europe inthe latter part of the eighteenth century.
resperse: To sprinkle; to scatter. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
rocking-horse: The figure of a horse, mounted upon rockers, for children toride.
radical: Relating, or belonging, to the root, or ultimate source ofderivation; as, a radical verbal form.
repaint: To paint anew or again; as, to repaint a house; to repaint theground of a picture.
reconcentrate: To concentrate again; to concentrate thoroughly.
rival: Having the same pretensions or claims; standing in competitionfor superiority; as, rival lovers; rival claims or pretensions.The strenuous conflicts and alternate victories of two rivalconfederacies of statesmen. Macaulay.
resultance: The act of resulting; that which results; a result. Donne.
rapidity: The quality or state of being rapid; swiftness; celerity;velocity; as, the rapidity of growth or improvement.
rumseller: One who sells rum; one who deals in intoxicating liquors;especially, one who sells spirituous beverages at retail.
ropeband: A small piece of spun yarn or marline, used to fasten the headof the sail to the spar. [Written also roband, and robbin.]
roughshod: Shod with shoes armed with points or calks; as, a roughshodhorse. To ride roughshod, to pursue a course regardless of the painor distress it may cause others.
rusticity: The quality or state of being rustic; rustic manners; rudeness;simplicity; artlessness.The sweetness and rusticity of a pastoral can not be so wellexpressed in any other tongue as in the Greek, when rightly mixed andqualified with the Doric dialect. Addison.The Saxons were refined from their rusticity. Sir W. Scott.
retouch: To correct or change, as a negative, by handwork.
rochelle: A seaport town in France. Rochelle powders. Same as Seidlitzpowders.-- Rochelle salt (Chem.), the double tartrate of sodium andpotassium, a white crystalline substance. It has a cooling, saline,slightly bitter taste and is employed as a mild purgative. It wasdiscovered by Seignette, an apothecary of Rochelle, and is calledalso Seignete's salt.
retribute: To pay back; to give in return, as payment, reward, orpunishment; to requite; as, to retribute one for his kindness; toretribute just punishment to a criminal. [Obs. or R.] Locke.
retrait: A portrait; a likeness. [Obs.]Whose fair retrait I in my shield do bear. Spenser.
relieving: Serving or tending to relieve. Relieving arch (Arch.), adischarging arch. See under Discharge, v. t.-- Relieving tackle. (Naut.) (a) A temporary tackle attached to thetiller of a vessel during gales or an action, in case of accident tothe tiller ropes. (b) A strong tackle from a wharf to a careenedvessel, to prevent her from going over entirely, and to assist inrighting her. Totten. Craig.
revince: To overcome; to refute, as error. [Obs.] Foxe.
roral: Of or pertaining to dew; consisting of dew; dewy. [R.] M.Green.
reanswer: To answer in return; to repay; to compensate; to make amendsfor.Which in weight to reanswer, his pettiness would bow under. Shak.
rap: A lay or skein containing 120 yards of yarn. Knight.
rivulet: A small stream or brook; a streamlet.By fountain or by shady rivulet He sought them. Milton.
ratio: The relation which one quantity or magnitude has to another ofthe same kind. It is expressed by the quotient of the division of thefirst by the second; thus, the ratio of 3 to 6 is expressed by a to bby a/b; or (less commonly) the second is made the dividend; as, a:b =b/a.
reintegrate: To renew with regard to any state or quality; to restore; tobring again together into a whole, as the parts off anything; toreas, to reintegrate a nation. Bacon.
reduce: To bring to the metallic state by separating from impurities;hence, in general, to remove oxygen from; to deoxidize; to combinewith, or to subject to the action of, hydrogen; as, ferric iron isreduced to ferrous iron; or metals are reduced from their ores; --opposed to Ant: oxidize.
refringent: Pertaining to, or possessing, refringency; refractive;refracting; as, a refringent prism of spar. Nichol.
regrede: To go back; to retrograde, as the apsis of a planet's orbit.[R.] Todhunter.
rubble: A mass or stratum of fragments or rock lying under thealluvium, and derived from the neighboring rock. Lyell.
revoice: To refurnish with a voice; to refit, as an organ pipe, so as torestore its tone.
raskolnik: One of the separatists or dissenters from the established orGreek church in Russia. [Written also rascolnik.]
receptary: Generally or popularly admitted or received. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
refiner: One who, or that which, refines.
reneye: To deney; to reject; to renounce. [Obs.]For he made every man reneye his law. Chaucer.
recent: Of or pertaining to the present or existing epoch; as, recentshells.
rosetta wood: An east Indian wood of a reddish orange color, handsomelyveined with darker marks. It is occasionally used for cabinetwork.Ure.
ribald: A low, vulgar, brutal, foul-mouthed wretch; a lewd fellow.Spenser. Pope.Ribald was almost a class name in the feudal system . . . He was hispatron's parasite, bulldog, and tool . . . It is not to be wonderedat that the word rapidly became a synonym for everything ruffianlyand brutal. Earle.
retentive: Having power to retain; as, a retentive memory.Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron, Can be retentive tothe strength of spirit. Shak.
revenge: To take vengeance; -- with upon. [Obs.] "A bird that willrevenge upon you all." Shak.
redemptory: Paid for ransom; serving to redeem. "Hector's redemptoryprice." Chapman.
rufol: A phenol derivative of anthracene obtained as a whitecrystalline substance, which on oxidation produces a red dyestuffrelated to anthraquinone.
re-store: To store again; as, the goods taken out were re-stored.
relativeness: The state of being relative, or having relation; relativity.
resuscitation: The act of resuscitating, or state of being resuscitated.The subject of resuscitation by his sorceries. Sir W. Scott.
rhipipter: One of the Rhipiptera, a group of insects having wings whichfold like a fan; a strepsipter.
refind: To find again; to get or experience again. Sandys.
rogatory: Seeking information; authorized to examine witnesses orascertain facts; as, a rogatory commission. Woolsey.
revenging: Executing revenge; revengeful.-- Re*ven"ging*ly, adv. Shak.
revulsion: The act of turning or diverting any disease from one part ofthe body to another. It resembles derivation, but is usually appliedto a more active form of counter irritation.
rullichies: Chopped meat stuffed into small bags of tripe. They are cut inslices and fried. [Local, New York]
raven: A large black passerine bird (Corvus corax), similar to thecrow, but larger. It is native of the northern part of Europe, Asiaand America, and is noted for its sagacity. Sea raven (Zoöl.), thecormorant.
reexaminable: Admitting of being reëxamined or reconsidered. Story.
renal: Of or pertaining to the kidneys; in the region of the kidneys.Renal calculus (Med.), a concretion formed in the excretory passagesof the kidney.-- Renal capsules or glands, the suprarenal capsules. See underCapsule.-- Renal casts, Renal colic. (Med.) See under Cast, and Colic.
redressless: Not having redress; such as can not be redressed; irremediable.Sherwood.
requisitory: Sought for; demanded. [R.] Summary on Du Bartas (1621).
ruffian: brutal; cruel; savagely boisterous; murderous; as, ruffianrage.
roquelaure: A cloak reaching about to, or just below, the knees, worn inthe 18th century. [Written also roquelo.]
remissly: In a remiss or negligent manner; carelessly.
roseworm: The larva of any one of several species of lepidopterousinsects which feed upon the leaves, buds, or blossoms of the rose,especially Cacæcia rosaceana, which rolls up the leaves for a nest,and devours both the leaves and buds.
reduplicate: Valvate with the margins curved outwardly; -- said of the
radicel: A small branch of a root; a rootlet.
requirable: Capable of being required; proper to be required. Sir M. Hale.
ruffianly: Like a ruffian; bold in crimes; characteristic of a ruffian;violent; brutal.
ravehook: A tool, hooked at the end, for enlarging or clearing seams forthe reception of oakum.
raillery: Pleasantry or slight satire; banter; jesting language;satirical merriment.Let raillery be without malice or heat. B. Jonson.Studies employed on low objects; the very naming of them issufficient to turn them into raillery. Addison.
rhachiodont: Having gular teeth formed by a peculiar modification of theinferior spines of some of the vertebræ, as certain South Africansnakes (Dasypelits) which swallow birds' eggs and use these gularteeth to crush them.
retirade: A kind of retrenchment, as in the body of a bastion, which maybe disputed inch by inch after the defenses are dismantled. Itusually consists of two faces which make a reëntering angle.
rizzar: To dry in the sun; as, rizzared haddock. [Scot.]
readmission: The act of admitting again, or the state of being readmitted;as, the readmission fresh air into an exhausted receiver; thereadmission of a student into a seminary.
rewin: To win again, or win back.The Palatinate was not worth the rewinning. Fuller.
rumination: The regurgitation of food from the stomach after it has beenswallowed, -- occasionally oberved as a morbid phenomenon in man.
reorient: Rising again. [R.]The life reorient out of dust. Tennyson.
rousant: Rising; -- applied to a bird in the attitude of rising; also,sometmes, to a bird in profile with wings addorsed.
refugee: The quality of being refulgent; brilliancy; splender; radiance.
red-tapist: One who is tenacious of a strict adherence to officialformalities. Ld. Lytton.
reseminate: To produce again by means of seed. [Obs.] Sir. T. Browne.
radiant: Giving off rays; -- said of a bearing; as, the sun radiant; acrown radiant.
roe: The ova or spawn of fishes and amphibians, especially whenstill inclosed in the ovarian membranes. Sometimes applied, loosely,to the sperm and the testes of the male.
resupine: Lying on the back; supine; hence, careless. Sir K. Digby.He spake, and, downward swayed, fell resupine, With his huge neckaslant. Cowper.
rejoinder: The defendant's answer to the plaintiff's replication.
riffler: A curved file used in carving wool and marble.
regenerateness: The quality or state of being rgenerate.
reparable: Capable of being repaired, restored to a sound or good state,or made good; restorable; as, a reparable injury.
rheic: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid (commonly calledchrysophanic acid) found in rhubarb (Rheum). [Obsoles.]
runcinate: Pinnately cut with the lobes pointing downwards, as the leaf ofthe dandelion.
romping: Inclined to romp; indulging in romps.A little romping girl from boarding school. W. Irving.
rad: imp. & p. p. of Read, Rede. Spenser.
ripidolite: A translucent mineral of a green color and micaceous structure,belonging to the chlorite group; a hydrous silicate of alumina,magnesia, and iron; -- called also clinochlore.
ranker: One who ranks, or disposes in ranks; one who arranges.
retentor: A muscle which serves to retain an organ or part in place, esp.when retracted. See Illust. of Phylactolemata.
recreation: The act of recreating, or the state of being recreated;refreshment of the strength and spirits after toil; amusement;diversion; sport; pastime.
relicted: Left uncovered, as land by recession of water. Bouvier.
razed: Slashed or striped in patterns. [Obs.] "Two Provincial roses onmy razed shoes." Shak.
rima: A narrow and elongated aperture; a cleft; a fissure.
runnel: A rivulet or small brook.Buddling rundels joined the sound. Collins.By the very sides of the way . . . there are slow runnels, in whichone can see the minnows swimming. Masson.
retinal: Of or pertaining to the retina. Retinal purple (Physiol.Chem.), the visual purple.
restorer: One who, or that which, restores.
retractive: Serving to retract; of the nature of a retraction.-- Re*tract"ive*ly, adv.
reassociate: To associate again; to bring again into close relatoins.
riparian: Of or pertaining to the bank of a river; as, riparian rights.
reiter: A German cavalry soldier of the fourteenth and fifteenthcenturies.
reconduct: To conduct back or again. "A guide to reconduct thy steps."Dryden.
ray: Array; order; arrangement; dress. [Obs.]And spoiling all her gears and goodly ray. Spenser.
roughtail: Any species of small ground snakes of the family Uropeltidæ; --so called from their rough tails.
rabdomancy: Divination by means of rods or wands. [Written alsorhabdomancy.]  Sir T. Browne.
risky: Attended with risk or danger; hazardous. "A risky matter." W.Collins.Generalization are always risky. Lowell.
raucity: Harshness of sound; rough utterance; hoarseness; as, theraucity of a trumpet, or of the human voice.
roke: Parched Indian corn, pounded up and mixed with sugar; -- calledalso yokeage. [Local, U.S.]
rove: To shoot at rovers; hence, to shoot at an angle of elevation,not at point-blank (rovers usually being beyond the point-blankrange).Fair Venusson that with thy cruel dart At that good knoght cunninglydidst rove. Spenser.
rubiaceous: Of or pertaining to a very large natural order of plants(Rubiaceæ) named after the madder (Rubia tinctoria), and includingabout three hundred and seventy genera and over four thousandspecies. Among them are the coffee tree, the trees yielding peruvianbark and quinine, the madder, the quaker ladies, and the treesbearing the edible fruits called genipap and Sierre Leone peach,besides many plants noted for the beauty or the fragrance of theirblossoms.
retitelae: A group of spiders which spin irregular webs; -- called alsoRetitelariæ.
reward: To give in return, whether good or evil; -- commonly in a goodsense; to requite; to recompense; to repay; to compensate.After the deed that is done, one doom shall reward, Mercy or no mercyas truth will accord. Piers Plowman.Thou hast rewarded me good, whereas I have rewarded thee evil. 1 Sam.xxiv. 17.I will render vengeance to mine enemies, and will reward them thathate me. Deut. xxxii. 41.God rewards those that have made use of the single talent. Hammond.
relatedness: The state or condition of being related; relationship;affinity. [R.] Emerson.
resonant: Returning, or capable of returning, sound; fitted to resound;resounding; echoing back.Through every hour of the golden morning, the streets were resonantwith female parties of young and old. De Quincey.
roundure: Roundness; a round or circle. [Obs.] Shak.
reliquary: A depositary, often a small box or casket, in which relics arekept.
recapitulate: To repeat, as the principal points in a discourse, argument, oressay; to give a summary of the principal facts, points, or argumentsof; to relate in brief; to summarize.
ruse: An artifice; trick; stratagem; wile; fraund; deceit. Ruse deguerre ( Etym: [F.], a stratagem of war.
regrate: To remove the outer surface of, as of an old hewn stone, so asto give it a fresh appearance.
recency: The state or quality of being recent; newness; new state; lateorigin; lateness in time; freshness; as, the recency of atransaction, of a wound, etc.
retry: To try (esp. judicially) a second time; as, to retry a case; toretry an accused person.
rubiacin: A substance found in madder root, and probably identical withruberythrinic acid.
rabble: An iron bar, with the end bent, used in stirring or skimmingmolten iron in the process of puddling.
replication: The reply of the plaintiff, in matters of fact, to thedefendant's plea.
repedation: A stepping or going back. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
resorcylic: Of, or pertaining to, or producing, resorcin; as, resorcylicacid.
redented: Formed like the teeth of a saw; indented.
rigidulous: Somewhat rigid or stiff; as, a rigidulous bristle.
reptantia: A divisiom of gastropods; the Pectinibranchiata.
repairer: One who, or that which, repairs, restores, or makes amends.
reality: Loyalty; devotion. [Obs.]To express our reality to the emperor. Fuller.
reniform: Having the form or shape of a kidney; as, a reniform mineral; areniform leaf.
raia: A genus of rays which includes the skates. See Skate.
radio-flagellata: A group of Protozoa having both flagella and pseudopodia.
receptible: Such as may be received; receivable.
ramiform: Having the form of a branch.
resultant: Resulting or issuing from a combination; existing or followingas a result or consequence. Resultant force or motion (Mech.), aforce which is the result of two or more forces acting conjointly, ora motion which is the result of two or more motions combined. SeeComposition of forces, under Composition.
rhizine: A rootlike filament or hair growing from the stems of mosses oron lichens; a rhizoid.
repetitious: Repeating; containing repetition. [U.S.] Dr. T. Dwight.
revert: To change back. See Revert, v. i. To revert a series (Alg.), totreat a series, as y = a + bx + cx2 + etc., where one variable y isexpressed in powers of a second variable x, so as to find therefromthe second variable x, expressed in a series arranged in powers of y.
red-gum: An eruption of red pimples upon the face, neck, and arms, inearly infancy; tooth rash; strophulus. Good.
rutinose: A disaccharide present in glycosides. Prepared from rutin byhydrolysis with rhamnodiastase. 6-O-a-L-rhamnosyl-D-glucose;C12H22O10.
redtop: A kind of grass (Agrostis vulgaris) highly valued in the UnitedStates for pasturage and hay for cattle; -- called also Englishgrass, and in some localities herd's grass. See Illustration inAppendix. The tall redtop is Triodia seslerioides.
revestiary: The apartment, in a church or temple, where the vestments,etc., are kept; -- now contracted into vestry.
revulse: To pull back with force. [R.] Cowper.
radicalness: Quality or state of being radical.
reconjoin: To join or conjoin anew. Boyle.
resorb: To swallow up.Now lifted by the tide, and now resorbed. Young.
rabinet: A kind of small ordnance formerly in use. [Written alsorabanet.] Ainsworth.
ruffianage: Ruffians, collectively; a body of ruffians. "The vilestruffianage." Sir F. Palgrave.
ringent: Having the lips widely separated and gaping like an open mouth;as a ringent bilabiate corolla.
red-light district: A district or neighborhood in which disorderly resorts arefrequent; -- so called in allusion to the red light kept in front ofmany such resorts at night. [Colloq. or Cant]
regalia: A kind of cigar of large size and superior quality; also, thesize in which such cigars are classed.
racemiform: Having the form of a raceme. Gray.
republicate: To make public again; to republish. [Obs.]
re-let: To let anew, as a hous.
rhachilla: A branch of inflorescence; the zigzag axis on which the floretsare arranged in the spikelets of grasses.
relais: A narrow space between the foot of the rampart and the scarp ofthe ditch, serving to receive the earth that may crumble off or bewashed down, and prevent its falling into the ditch. Wilhelm.
roebuck: A small European and Asiatic deer (Capreolus capræa) havingerect, cylindrical, branched antlers, forked at the summit. This, thesmallest European deer, is very nimble and graceful. It alwaysprefers a mountainous country, or high grounds.
retrieve: To discover and bring in game that has been killed or wounded;as, a dog naturally inclined to retrieve. Walsh.
robbery: The crime of robbing. See Rob, v. t., 2.
ralstonite: A fluoride of alumina and soda occurring with the Greenlandcryolite in octahedral crystals.
reticent: Inclined to keep silent; reserved; uncommunicative.
ratify: To approve and sanction; to make valid; to establish; tosettle; especially, to give sanction to, as something done by anagent or servant; as, to ratify an agreement, treaty, or contract; toratify a nomination.It is impossible for the divine power to set a seal to a lie byratifying an imposture with such a miracle. South.
rosewood: A valuable cabinet wood of a dark red color, streaked andvariegated with black, obtained from several tropical leguminoustrees of the genera Dalbergia and Machærium. The finest kind is fromBrazil, and is said to be from the Dalbergia nigra. African rosewood,the wood of the leguminous tree Pterocarpus erinaceus.-- Jamaica rosewood, the wood of two West Indian trees (Amyrisbalsamifera, and Linocieria ligustrina).-- New South Wales rosewood, the wood of Trichilia glandulosa, atree related to the margosa.
ringmaster: One in charge of the performances (as of horses) within thering in a circus.
refulgent: Casting a bright light; radiant; brilliant; resplendent;shining; splendid; as, refulgent beams.-- Re*ful"gent*ly, adv.So conspicuous and refulgent a truth. Boyle.
redoubt: To stand in dread of; to regard with fear; to dread. [R.]
reland: To land again; to put on land, as that which had been shippedor embarked.
rhizopodous: Of or pertaining to the rhizopods.
ravelin: A detached work with two embankments with make a salient angle.It is raised before the curtain on the counterscarp of the place.Formerly called demilune and half-moon.
recollect: A friar of the Strict Observance, -- an order of Franciscans.[Written also Recollet.] Addis & Arnold.
rostriform: Having the form of a beak.
reciprocally: In the manner of reciprocals. Reciprocally proportional (Arith.& Alg.), proportional, as two variable quantities, so that the oneshall have a constant ratio to the reciprocal of the other.
rabdology: The method or art of performing arithmetical operations bymeans of Napier's bones. See Napier's bones. [Written alsorhabdology.]
recompilement: The act of recompiling; new compilation or digest; as, arecompilement of the laws. Bacon.
rabidness: The quality or state of being rabid.
ringtoss: A game in which the object is to toss a ring so that it willcatch upon an upright stick.
round-shouldered: Having the shoulders stooping or projecting; round-backed.
rhinencephalon: The division of the brain in front of the prosencephalon,consisting of the two olfactory lobes from which the olfactory nervesarise.
retail: The sale of commodities in small quantities or parcels; --opposed to wholesale; sometimes, the sale of commodities at secondhand.
reeden: Consisting of a reed or reeds.Through reeden pipes convey the golden flood. Dryden.
rhigolene: A mixture of volatile hydrocarbons intermediate between gsoleneand cymogene. It is obtained in the purification of crude petroleum,and is used as a refregerant.
renverse: To reverse. [Obs.]Whose shield he bears renverst. Spenser.
republish: To publish anew; specifically, to publish in one country (awork first published in another); also, to revive (a will) by reSubsecquent to the purchase or contract, the devisor republished hiswill. Blackstone.
reviver: One who, or that which, revives.
regardful: Heedful; attentive; observant.-- Re*gard"ful*ly, adv.Let a man be very tender and regardful of every pious motion made bythe Spirit of God to his heart. South.
reprobative: Of or pertaining to reprobation; expressing reprobation.
rambutan: A Malayan fruit produced by the tree Nephelium lappaceum, andclosely related to the litchi nut. It is bright red, oval in shape,covered with coarse hairs (whence the name), and contains a pleasantacid pulp. Called also ramboostan.
revolution: The motion of any body, as a planet or satellite, in a curvedline or orbit, until it returns to the same point again, or to apoint relatively the same; -- designated as the annual, anomalistic,nodical, sidereal, or tropical revolution, according as the point ofreturn or completion has a fixed relation to the year, the anomaly,the nodes, the stars, or the tropics; as, the revolution of the earthabout the sun; the revolution of the moon about the earth.
ranch: To wrench; to tear; to sprain; to injure by violent strainingor contortion. [R.] Dryden. "Hasting to raunch the arrow out."Spenser.
roon: Vermilion red; red. [R.]Her face was like the lily roon. J. R. Drake.
refel: To refute; to disprove; as, to refel the tricks of a sophister.[Obs.]How he refelled me, and how I replied. Shak.
recluse: Shut up, sequestered; retired from the world or from publicnotice; solitary; living apart; as, a recluse monk or hermit; arecluse lifeIn meditation deep, recluse From human converse. J. Philips.
rigmarole: A succession of confused or nonsencial statements; foolishtalk; nonsense. [Colloq.]Often one's dear friend talks something which one scruples to callrigmarole. De Quincey.
reverend: Worthy of reverence; entitled to respect mingled with fear andaffection; venerable.A reverend sire among them came. Milton.They must give good example and reverend deportment in the face oftheir children. Jer. Taylor.
reservee: One to, or for, whom anything is reserved; -- contrasted withreservor.
rescussee: The party in whose favor a rescue is made. Crabb.
rightness: Straightness; as, the rightness of a line. Bacon.
ruck: A roc. [Obs. or prov. Eng.] Drayton.
remission: A temporary and incomplete subsidence of the force or violenceof a disease or of pain, as destinguished from intermission, in whichthe disease completely leaves the patient for a time; abatement.
readjust: To adjust or settle again; to put in a different order orrelation; to rearrange.
resinous: Of or pertaining to resin; of the nature of resin; resemblingor obtained from resin. Resinous electricity (Elec.), electricitywhich is exited by rubbing bodies of the resinous kind. See Negativeelectricity, under Negative.
relatively: In a relative manner; in relation or respect to something else;not absolutely.Consider the absolute affections of any being as it is in itself,before you consider it relatively. I. Watts.
relay cylinder: In a variable expansion central-valve engine, a small auxiliaryengine for automatically adjusting the steam distribution to the loadon the main engine.[Webster 1913 Suppl.]
rynd: A piece of iron crossing the hole in the upper millstone bywhich the stone is supported on the spindle.
rollic: To move or play in a careless, swaggering manner, with afrolicsome air; to frolic; to sport; commonly in the form rollicking.[Colloq.]He described his friends as rollicking blades. T. Hook.
redeemableness: The quality or state of being redeemable; redeemability.
refect: To restore after hunger or fatique; to refresh. [Archaic] SirT. Browne.
retrenchment: A work constructed within another, to prolong the defense ofthe position when the enemy has gained possession of the outer work;or to protect the defenders till they can retreat or obtain terms fora capitulation.
readability: The state of being readable; readableness.
readdress: To address a second time; -- often used reflexively.He readdressed himself to her. Boyle.
reiterative: A word expressing repeated or reiterated action.
riotry: The act or practice of rioting; riot. "Electioneering riotry."Walpole.
risk: Hazard of loss; liabillity to loss in property. To run a risk,to incur hazard; to encounter danger.
roching cask: A tank in which alum is crystallized from a solution.
ruminator: One who ruminates or muses; a meditator.
rosebush: The bush or shrub which bears roses.
rist: 3d pers. sing. pres. of Rise, contracted from riseth. Chaucer.
resupination: The state of luing on the back; the state of being resupinate,or reversed.Our Vitruvius calleth this affection in the eye a resupination of thefigure. Sir H. Wotton.
reclusive: Affording retirement from society. "Some reclusive andreligious life." Shak.
rope-yarn: the yarn or thread of any stuff of which the strands of a ropeare made.
rhinal: Og or pertaining to the nose or olfactory organs.
rebaptize: To baptize again or a second time.
revocable: Capable of being revoked; as, a revocable edict or grant; arevocable covenant.-- Rev"o*ca*ble*ness, n.-- Rev"o*ca*bly, adv.
reglet: A flat, narrow molding, used chiefly to separate the parts ormembers of compartments or panels from one another, or doubled,turned, and interlaced so as to form knots, frets, or otherornaments. See Illust. (12) of Column.
relay governor: A speed regulator, as a water-wheel governor, embodying therelay principle.[Webster 1913 Suppl.]
ravissant: In a half-raised position, as if about to spring on prey.
rite: The act of performing divine or solemn service, as establishedby law, precept, or custom; a formal act of religion or other solemnduty; a solemn observance; a ceremony; as, the rites of freemasonry.He looked with indifference on rites, names, and forms ofecclesiastical polity. Macaulay.
rhachidian: Of or pertaining to the rhachis; as, the rhachidian teeth of amollusk.
rhamnus: A genus of shrubs and small trees; buckthorn. The CaliforniaRhamnus Purchianus and the European R. catharticus are used inmedicine. The latter is used for hedges.
restringency: Quality or state of being restringent; astringency. [Obs.] SirW. Petty.
refit: To obtain repairs or supplies; as, the fleet returned to refit.
rageful: Full of rage; expressing rage. [Obs.] "Rageful eyes." Sir P.Sidney.
relay: To lay again; to lay a second time; as, to relay a pavement.
ruffed: Furnished with a ruff. Ruffed grouse (Zoöl.), a North Americangrouse (Bonasa umbellus) common in the wooded districts of theNorthern United States. The male has a ruff of brown or blackfeathers on each side of the neck, and is noted for the loud drummingsound he makes during the breeding season. Called also tippet grouse,partridge, birch partridge, pheasant, drummer, and white-flesher.-- ruffed lemur (Zoöl.), a species of lemur (lemur varius) having aconspicuous ruff on the sides of the head. Its color is varied withblack and white. Called also ruffed maucaco.
rebarbarize: To reduce again to barbarism.-- Re*bar`ba*ri*za"tion, n.Germany . . . rebarbarized by polemical theology and religious wars.Sir W. Hamilton.
refined: Freed from impurities or alloy; purifed; polished; cultured;delicate; as; refined gold; refined language; refined sentiments.Refined wits who honored poesy with their pens. Peacham.-- Re*fin"ed*ly (r, adv.-- Re*fin"ed*ness, n.
raspy: Like a rasp, or the sound made by a rasp; grating. R. D.Blackmore.
rhomb: An equilateral parallelogram, or quadrilateral figure whosesides are equal and the opposite sides parallel. The angles may beunequal, two being obtuse and two acute, as in the cut, or the anglesmay be equal, in which case it is usually called a square.
ramson: A broad-leaved species of garlic (Allium ursinum), common inEuropean gardens; -- called also buckram.
rale: An adventitious sound, usually of morbid origin, accompanyingthe normal respiratory sounds. See Rhonchus.
remover: One who removes; as, a remover of landmarks. Bacon.
resonance: A prolongation or increase of any sound, eithar by reflection,as in a cavern or apartment the walls of which are not distant enoughto return a distinct echo, or by the production of vibrations inother bodies, as a sounding-board, or the bodies of musicalinstruments. Pulmonary resonance (Med.), the sound heard onpercussing over the lungs.-- Vocal resonance (Med.), the sound transmitted to the ear whenauscultation is made while the patient is speaking.
reconvertible: Capable of being reconverted; convertible again to the originalform or condition.
rutterkin: An old crafty fox or beguiler -- a word of contempt. [Obs.]Cotgrave.
rukh: A large bird, supposed by some to be the same as the extinctEpiornis of Madagascar. [Obs.]
ruthless: Having no ruth; cruel; pitiless.Their rage the hostile bands restrain, All but the ruthless monarchof the main. Pope.-- Ruth"less*ly, adv.-- Ruth"less*ness, n.
releaser: One who releases, or sets free.
rivet: A metallic pin with a head, used for uniting two plates orpieces of material together, by passing it through them and thenbeating or pressing down the point so that it shall spread out andform a second head; a pin or bolt headed or clinched at both ends.With busy hammers closing rivets up. Shak. Rivet joint, or Rivetedjoint, a joint between two or more pieces secured by rivets.
retainment: The act of retaining; retention. Dr. H. More.
rectification: The determination of a straight line whose length is equal aportion of a curve. Rectification of a globe (Astron.), itsadjustment preparatory to the solution of a proposed problem.
rampageous: Characterized by violence and passion; unruly; rampant. [Prov.or Low]In the primitive ages of a rampageous antiquity. Galt.
rhemish: Of or pertaining to Rheimis, or Reima, in France. RhemishTestament, the English version of the New Testament used by RomanCatholics. See Douay Bible.
remunerate: To pay an equivalent to for any service, loss, expense, orother sacrifice; to recompense; to requite; as, to remunerate men forlabor.
refrigerate: To cause to become cool; to make or keep cold or cool.
renerve: To nerve again; to give new vigor to; to reinvigorate.
retromingency: The quality or state of being retromingent. Sir T. Browne.
regratiatory: A returning or giving of thanks. [Obs.] Skelton.
ruffianish: Having the qualities or manners of a ruffian; ruffianly.
residuum: That which is left after any process of separation orpurification; that which remains after certain specified deductionsare made; residue."I think so," is the whole residuum . . . after evaporating theprodigious pretensions of the zealot demagogue. L. Taylor.
res: A thing; the particular thing; a matter; a point. Res gestae [L., things done] (Law), the facts which form the environmentof a litigated issue. Wharton.-- Res judicata [L.] (Law), a thing adjudicated; a matter no longeropen to controversy.
revivalism: The spirit of religious revivals; the methods of revivalists.
recitative: A species of musical recitation in which the words aredelivered in manner resembling that of ordinary declamation; also, apiece of music intended for such recitation; -- opposed to melisma.
radial engine: An engine, usually an internal-combustion engine of a certaintype (the radial type) having several cylinders arranged radiallylike the spokes of a complete wheel. The semiradial engine hasradiating cylinders on only one side of the crank shaft.
remit: To transmit or send, esp. to a distance, as money in payment ofa demand, account, draft, etc.; as, he remitted the amount by mail.
rejoice: To feel joy; to experience gladness in a high degree; to havepleasurable satisfaction; to be delighted. "O, rejoice beyond acommon joy." Shak.I will be glad and rejoice in thy mercy. Ps. xxxi. 7.
resell: To sell again; to sell what has been bought or sold; to retail.
rationalness: The quality or state of being rational; rationality.
repartimiento: A partition or distribution, especially of slaves; also, anassessment of taxes. W. Irving.
rejuvenescent: Becoming, or causing to become, rejuvenated; rejuvenating.
redhibition: The annulling of a sale, and the return by the buyer of thearticle sold, on account of some defect.
ragwork: A kind of rubblework. In the United States, any rubblework ofthin and small stones.
red-tapism: Strict adherence to official formalities. J. C. Shairp.
rebus: A pictorial suggestion on a coat of arms of the name of theperson to whom it belongs. See Canting arms, under Canting.
requicken: To quicken anew; to reanimate; to give new life to. Shak.
rex: A king. To play rex, to play the king; to domineer. [Obs.]
rackarock: A Sprengel explosive consisting of potassium chlorate and mono-nitrobenzene.
relegate: To remove, usually to an inferior position; to consign; totransfer; specifically, to send into exile; to banish.It [the Latin language] was relegated into the study of the scholar.Milman.
refresher: An extra fee paid to counsel in a case that has been adjournedfrom one term to another, or that is unusually protracted.Ten guineas a day is the highest refresher which a counsel cancharge. London Truth.
revibrate: To vibrate back or in return.-- Re`vi*bra"tion, n.
riparious: Growing along the banks of rivers; riparian.
recidivist: One who is recidivous or is characterized by recidivism; anincorrigible criminal. -- Re*cid`i*vis"tic (#), a.
receivedness: The state or quality of being received, accepted, or current;as, the receivedness of an opinion. Boyle.
respondent: Disposed or expected to respond; answering; according;corresponding.Wealth respondent to payment and contributions. Bacon.
reverse: Reversed; as, a reverse shell. Reverse bearing (Surv.), thebearing of a back station as observed from the station next inadvance.-- Reverse curve (Railways), a curve like the letter S, formed oftwo curves bending in opposite directions.-- Reverse fire (Mil.), a fire in the rear.-- Reverse operation (Math.), an operation the steps of which aretaken in a contrary order to that in which the same or similar stepsare taken in another operation considered as direct; an operation inwhich that is sought which in another operation is given, and thatgiven which in the other is sought; as, finding the length of apendulum from its time of vibration is the reverse operation tofinding the time of vibration from the length.
rectify: To refine or purify by repeated distillation or sublimation, bywhich the fine parts of a substance are separated from the grosser;as, to rectify spirit of wine.
ravening: Eagerness for plunder; rapacity; extortion. Luke xi. 39.
rebec: An instrument formerly used which somewhat resembled theviolin, having three strings, and being played with a bow. [Writtenalso rebeck.] Milton.He turn'd his rebec to a mournful note. Drayton.
repurchase: To buy back or again; to regain by purchase. Sir M. Hale.
reexportation: The act of reëxporting, or of exporting an import. A. Smith.
radicant: Taking root on, or above, the ground; rooting from the stem, asthe trumpet creeper and the ivy.
radiator: That which radiates or emits rays, whether of light or heat;especially, that part of a heating apparatus from which the heat isradiated or diffused; as, a stream radiator.
rabbinic: The language or dialect of the rabbins; the later Hebrew.
ra-: A prefix, from the Latin re and ad combined, coming to usthrough the French and Italian. See Re-, and Ad-.
restiness: The quality or state of being resty; sluggishness. [Obs.]The snake by restiness and lying still all winter. Holland.
rankly: With rank or vigorous growth; luxuriantly; hence, coarsely;grossly; as, weeds grow rankly.
reforest: To replant with trees; to reafforest; to reforestize.
rape: Sexual connection with a woman without her consent. See Age ofconsent, under Consent, n. statutory rape.
resolvable: Admitting of being resolved; admitting separation intoconstituent parts, or reduction to first principles; admittingsolution or explanation; as, resolvable compounds; resolvable ideasor difficulties.
rong: imp. & p. p. of Ring. Chaucer.
reclination: The angle which the plane of the dial makes with a verticalplane which it intersects in a horizontal line. Brande & C.
regal: Of or pertaining to a king; kingly; royal; as, regal authority,pomp, or sway. "The regal title." Shak.He made a scorn of his regal oath. Milton.
regimental: Belonging to, or concerning, a regiment; as, regimentalofficers, clothing. Regimental school, in the British army, a schoolfor the instruction of the private soldiers of a regiment, and theirchildren, in the rudimentary branches of education.
rockery: A mound formed of fragments of rock, earth, etc., and set withplants.
recoil: To draw or go back. [Obs.] Spenser.
rennet: A name of many different kinds of apples. Cf. Reinette.Mortimer.
rememberable: Capable or worthy of being remembered.-- Re*mem"ber*a*bly, adv.The whole vale of Keswick is so rememberable. Coleridge.
ralph: A name sometimes given to the raven.
resignee: One to whom anything is resigned, or in whose favor aresignation is made.
reedling: The European bearded titmouse (Panurus biarmicus); -- calledalso reed bunting, bearded pinnock, and lesser butcher bird.
reebok: The peele. [Written also rehboc and rheeboc.]
ruiner: One who, or that which, ruins.
rudderhead: The upper end of the rudderpost, to which the tiller isattashed.
renunciation: Formal declination to take out letters of administration, or toassume an office, privilege, or right.
remora: Any one of several species of fishes belonging to Echeneis,Remora, and allied genera. Called also sucking fish.
ringhead: An instrument used for stretching woolen cloth.
ruddy: To make ruddy. [R.] Sir W. Scott.
robustious: Robust. [Obs. or Humorous] W. Irving.In Scotland they had handled the bishops in a more robustious manner.Milton.-- Ro*bus"tious*ly, adv.-- Ro*bus"tious*ness, n.
rhabdolith: A minute calcareous rodlike structure found both at the surfaceand the bottom of the ocean; -- supposed by some to be a calcareousalga.
rapturize: To put, or be put, in a state of rapture. [R.]
refitment: The act of refitting, or the state of being refitted.
rheomotor: Any apparatus by which an electrical current is originated.[R.]
rivose: Marked with sinuate and irregular furrows.
ribbonism: The principles and practices of the Ribbonmen. See RibbonSociety, under Ribbon.
ruridecanal: Of or pertaining to a rural dean; as, a ruridecanal district;the ruridecanal intellect. [R.]
rheumy: Of or pertaining to rheum; abounding in, or causing, rheum;affected with rheum.His head and rheumy eyes distill in showers. Dryden.And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air To add unto his sickness. Shak.
retrench: To furnish with a retrenchment; as, to retrench bastions.
redigest: To digest, or reduce to form, a second time. Kent.
rhymery: The art or habit of making rhymes; rhyming; -- in contempt.
reveille: The beat of drum, or bugle blast, about break of day, to givenotice that it is time for the soldiers to rise, and for thesentinels to forbear challenging. "Sound a reveille." Dryden.For at dawning to assail ye Here no bugles sound reveille. Sir W.Scott.
retiary: Any spider which spins webs to catch its prey.
refossion: The act of digging up again. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
reparative: Repairing, or tending to repair. Jer. Taylor.
ruelle: A private circle or assembly at a private house; a circle.[Obs.] Dryden.
recuse: To refuse or reject, as a judge; to challenge that the judgeshall not try the cause. [Obs.] Sir K. Digby.
rashly: In a rush manner; with precipitation.He that doth anything rashly, must do it willingly; for he was freeto deliberate or not. L'Estrange.
russ: Of or pertaining to the Russians.
ragtime: Time characterized by syncopation, as in many negro melodies.[Colloq.]
radiale: The bone or cartilage of the carpus which articulates with theradius and corresponds to the scaphoid bone in man.
retinoscopy: The study of the retina of the eye by means of theophthalmoscope.
rouser: A stirrer in a copper for boiling wort.
retiarius: A gladiator armed with a net for entangling his adversary and atrident for despatching him.
ragman: A man who collects, or deals in, rags.
russia: A country of Europe and Asia. Russia iron, a kind of sheet ironmade in Russia, having a lustrous blue-black surface.-- Russia leather, a soft kind of leather, made originally in Russiabut now elsewhere, having a peculiar odor from being impregnated withan oil obtained from birch bark. It is much used in bookbinding, onaccount of its not being subject to mold, and being proof againstinsects.-- Russia matting, matting manufactured in Russia from the innerbark of the linden (Tilia Europæa).
rata: A New Zealand forest tree (Metrosideros robusta), also, itshard dark red wood, used by the Maoris for paddles and war clubs.
regularia: A division of Echini which includes the circular, or regular,sea urchins.
reefer: One who reefs; -- a name often given to midshipmen. Marryat.
ricinine: A bitter white crystalline alkaloid extracted from the seeds ofthe castor-oil plant.
rubstone: A stone for scouring or rubbing; a whetstone; a rub.
ratepayer: One who pays rates or taxes.
rug: To pull roughly or hastily; to plunder; to spoil; to tear.[Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
re-search: To search again; to examine anew.
reckoner: One who reckons or computes; also, a book of calculation,tables, etc., to assist in reckoning.Reckoners without their host must reckon twice. Camden.
renter: One who rents or leases an estate; -- usually said of a lesseeor tenant.
rebuild: To build again, as something which has been demolished; toconstruct anew; as, to rebuild a house, a wall, a wharf, or a city.
regulative: Necessarily assumed by the mind as fundamental to all otherknowledge; furnishing fundamental principles; as, the regulativeprinciples, or principles a priori; the regulative faculty. Sir W.Hamilton.
rehibitory: Of or relating to rehibition; as, a rehibitory action.
ropewalk: A long, covered walk, or a low, level building, where ropes aremanufactured.
reverted: Turned back; reversed. Specifically: (Her.) Bent or curvedtwice, in opposite directions, or in the form of an S.
radio-active: Capable of luminescence under the action of cathode rays, Xrays, or any of the allied forms of radiation. -- Ra`di*o-ac*tiv"i*ty, n.
reef: A large vein of auriferous quartz; -- so called in Australia.Hence, any body of rock yielding valuable ore. Reef builder (Zoöl.),any stony coral which contributes material to the formation of coralreefs.-- Reef heron (Zoöl.), any heron of the genus Demigretta; as, theblue reef heron (D.jugularis) of Australia.
rutter: A horseman or trooper. [Obs.]Such a regiment of rutters Never defied men braver. Beau. & Fl.
remerge: To merge again. "Remerging in the general Soul." Tennyson.
rammel: Refuse matter. [Obs.]Filled with any rubbish, rammel and broken stones. Holland.
rue: A perennial suffrutescent plant (Ruta graveolens), having astrong, heavy odor and a bitter taste; herb of grace. It is used inmedicine.Then purged with euphrasy and rue The visual nerve, for he had muchto see. Milton.They [the exorcists] are to try the devil by holy water, incense,sulphur, rue, which from thence, as we suppose, came to be calledherb of grace. Jer. Taylor.
routously: With that violation of law called a rout. See 5th Rout, 4.
reezed: Grown rank; rancid; rusty. [Obs.] "Reezed bacon." Marston.
ripsaw: A handsaw with coarse teeth which have but a slight set, usedfor cutting wood in the direction of the fiber; -- called alsoripping saw.
roseroot: A fleshy-leaved herb (Rhodiola rosea); rosewort; -- so calledbecause the roots have the odor of roses.
rodomont: A vain or blustering boaster; a braggart; a braggadocio. Sir T.Herbert.
ride: To overlap (each other); -- said of bones or fracturedfragments. To ride a hobby, to have some favorite occupation orsubject of talk.-- To ride and tie, to take turn with another in labor and rest; --from the expedient adopted by two persons with one horse, one of whomrides the animal a certain distance, and then ties him for the use ofthe other, who is coming up on foot. Fielding.-- To ride down. (a) To ride over; to trample down in riding; tooverthrow by riding against; as, to ride down an enemy. (b) (Naut.)To bear down, as on a halyard when hoisting a sail.-- To ride out (Naut.), to keep safe afloat during (a storm) whileriding at anchor or when hove to on the open sea; as, to ride out thegale. to ride the lightning, (Colloq.) to be executed byelectrocution in an electric chair.
rapture: To transport with excitement; to enrapture. [Poetic] Thomson.
roborate: To give strength or support to; to confirm. [Obs.] Fuller.
redargution: The act of redarguing; refutation. [Obs. or R.] Bacon.
reputeless: Not having good repute; disreputable; disgraceful; inglorius.[R.] Shak.
rostellum: A small beaklike process or extension of some part; a smallrostrum; as, the rostellum of the stigma of violets, or of theoperculum of many mosses; the rostellum on the head of a tapeworm.
retrocedent: Disposed or likely to retrocede; -- said of diseases which gofrom one part of the body to another, as the gout.
reorganization: The act of reorganizing; a reorganized existence; as,reorganization of the troops.
reportorial: Of or pertaining to a reporter or reporters; as, thereportorial staff of a newspaper.
renewer: One who, or that which, renews.
rusty: Resembling, or covered with a substance resembling, rust;affected with rust; rubiginous.
rabblement: A tumultuous crowd of low people; a rabble. "Rude rablement."Spenser.
rectrix: One of the quill feathers of the tail of a bird.
rapt: imp. & p. p. of Rap, to snatch away.
rigol: A circle; hence, a diadem. [Obs.] Shak.
raip: A rope; also, a measure equal to a rod. [Scot.]
reichstag: The Diet, or House of Representatives, of the German empire,which is composed of members elected for a term of three years by thedirect vote of the people. See Bundesrath.
right-angled: Containing a right angle or right angles; as, a right-angledtriangle.
romanism: The tenets of the Church of Rome; the Roman Catholic religion.
runt: Any animal which is unusually small, as compared with others ofits kind; -- applied particulary to domestic animals.
rurally: In a rural manner; as in the country.
refringency: The power possessed by a substance to refract a ray; as,different substances have different refringencies. Nichol.
relievement: The act of relieving, or the state of being relieved; relief;release. [Archaic.]
ruin: To bring to ruin; to cause to fall to pieces and decay; to maketo perish; to bring to destruction; to bring to poverty orbankruptcy; to impair seriously; to damage essentially; to overthrow.this mortal house I'll ruin. Shak.By thee raised, I ruin all my foes. Milton.The eyes of other people are the eyes that ruin us. Franklin.By the fireside there are old men seated, Seeling ruined cities inthe ashes. Longfellow.
renouncement: The act of disclaiming or rejecting; renunciation. Shak.
recoveror: The demandant in a common recovery after judgment. Wharton.
ringtail: A bird having a distinct band of color across the tail, as thehen harrier.
rostellate: Having a rostellum, or small beak; terminating in a beak.
retexture: The act of weaving or forming again. Carlyle.
rhinoscopy: The examination or study of the soft palate, posterior nares,etc., by means of a laryngoscopic mirror introduced into the pharynx.
rakel: Hasty; reckless; rash. [Obs.] Chaucer.-- Ra"kel*ness, n. [Obs.] Chaucer.
reascent: A returning ascent or ascension; acclivity. Cowper.
recede: To cede back; to grant or yield again to a former possessor;as, to recede conquered territory.
rase: To be leveled with the ground; to fall; to suffer overthrow.[Obs.]
reachless: Being beyond reach; lofty.Unto a reachless pitch of praises hight. Bp. Hall.
residue: That part of a testeator's estate wwhich is not disposed of inhis will by particular and special legacies and devises, and whichremains after payment of debts and legacies.
recalcitration: A kicking back again; opposition; repugnance; refractoriness.
royne: To bite; to gnaw. [Written also roin.] [Obs.] Spenser.
raphaelism: The principles of painting introduced by Raphael, the Italianpainter.
redressment: The act of redressing; redress. Jefferson.
recumbent: Leaning; reclining; lying; as, the recumbent posture of theRomans at their meals. Hence, figuratively; Resting; inactive; idle.-- Re*cum"bent*ly, adv.
rorulent: Having the surface appearing as if dusty, or covered with finedew.
rotifera: An order of minute worms which usually have one or two groupsof vibrating cilia on the head, which, when in motion, often give anappearance of rapidly revolving wheels. The species are very numerousin fresh waters, and are very diversified in form and habits.
rutylene: A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H18, of the acetylene series. It isproduced artificially.
reform: To put into a new and improved form or condition; to restore toa former good state, or bring from bad to good; to change from worseto better; to amend; to correct; as, to reform a profligate man; toreform corrupt manners or morals.The example alone of a vicious prince will corrupt an age; but thatof a good one will not reform it. Swift.
reshipment: The act of reshipping; also, that which is reshippped.
rhabdophora: An extinct division of Hydrozoa which includes thegraptolities.
reticularia: An extensive division of rhizopods in which the pseudopodia aremore or less slender and coalesce at certain points, formingirregular meshes. It includes the shelled Foraminifera, together withsome groups which lack a true shell.
replum: The framework of some pods, as the cress, which remains afterthe valves drop off. Gray.
resume: A summing up; a condensed statement; an abridgment or briefrecapitulation.The exellent little résumé thereof in Dr. Landsborough's book. C.Kingsley.
receptive: Having the quality of receiving; able or inclined to take in,absorb, hold, or contain; receiving or containing; as, a receptivemind.Imaginary space is receptive of all bodies. Glanvill.
rollway: A place prepared for rolling logs into a stream.
rhea: The ramie or grass-cloth plant. See Grass-cloth plant, underGrass.
rigging: DRess; tackle; especially (Naut.), the ropes, chains, etc.,that support the masts and spars of a vessel, and serve as purchasesfor adjusting the sails, etc. See Illustr. of Ship and Sails. Runningrigging (Naut.), all those ropes used in bracing the yards, makingand shortening sail, etc., such as braces, sheets, halyards, clewlines, and the like.-- Standing rigging (Naut.), the shrouds and stays.
reclinate: Reclined, as a leaf; bent downward, so that the point, as of astem or leaf, is lower than the base.
rubicon: A small river which separated Italy from Cisalpine Gaul, theprovince alloted to Julius Cæsar.
rakish: Dissolute; lewd; debauched.The arduous task of converting a rakish lover. Macaulay.
reabsorb: To absorb again; to draw in, or imbibe, again what has beeneffused, extravasated, or thrown off; to swallow up again; as, toreabsorb chyle, lymph, etc.; -- used esp. of fluids.
rickrack: A kind of openwork edging made of serpentine braid.
rhizophora: A genus of trees including the mangrove. See Mangrove.
rounce: The handle by which the bed of a hand press, holding the formof type, etc., is run in under the platen and out again; -- sometimesapplied to the whole apparatus by which the form is moved under theplaten.
reciprocornous: Having horns turning backward and then forward, like those of aram. [R.] Ash.
reversed: Annulled and the contrary substituted; as, a reversed judgmentor decree. Reversed positive or negative (Photog.), a picturecorresponding with the original in light and shade, but reversed asto right and left. Abney.
refracture: A second breaking (as of a badly set bone) by the surgeon.
retrocopulation: Copulation from behind. Sir T. Browne.
round-up: The act of collecting or gathering together scattered cattle byriding around them and driving them in. [Western U.S.]
rappage: The enlargement of a molt caused by rapping the pattern.
reticular: Of or pertaining to a reticulum.
rutaceous: Of or pertaining to plants of a natural order (Rutacæ) of whichthe rue is the type, and which includes also the orange, lemon,dittany, and buchu.
reverberator: One who, or that which, produces reverberation.
roulade: A smoothly running passage of short notes (as semiquavers, orsixteenths) uniformly grouped, sung upon one long syllable, as inHandel's oratorios.
riflebird: Any one of several species of beautiful birds of Australia andNew Guinea, of the genera Ptiloris and Craspidophora, allied to theparadise birds.
regicidal: Pertaining to regicide, or to one committing it; having thenature of, or resembling, regicide. Bp. Warburton.
rumpus: A disturbance; noise and confusion; a quarrel. [Colloq.]
revolvency: The act or state of revolving; revolution. [Archaic]Its own revolvency upholds the world. Cowper.
rhinoplastic: Of or pertaining to rhinoplasty; as, a rhinoplastic operation.
redraw: To draw again; to make a second draft or copy of; to redraft.
repeat: To repay or refund (an excess received). To repeat one's self,to do or say what one has already done or said.-- To repeat signals, to make the same signals again; specifically,to communicate, by repeating them, the signals shown at headquarters.
recapitulation: The act of recapitulating; a summary, or concise statement orenumeration, of the principal points, facts, or statements, in apreceding discourse, argument, or essay.
retina: The delicate membrane by which the back part of the globe ofthe eye is lined, and in which the fibers of the optic nerveterminate. See Eye.
riot: The tumultuous disturbance of the public peace by an unlawfulassembly of three or more persons in the execution of some privateobject. To run riot, to act wantonly or without restraint.
raphaelesque: Like Raphael's works; in Raphael's manner of painting.
recognizee: The person in whose favor a recognizance is made. [Written alsorecognisee.] Blackstone.
revirescence: A growing green or fresh again; renewal of youth or vigor.[Obs.]
rufterhood: A kind of hood for a hawk.
retch: To make an effort to vomit; to strain, as in vomiting. [Writtenalso reach.]Beloved Julia, hear me still beseeching! (Here he grew inarticulatewith retching.) Byron.
rowan tree: A european tree (Pyrus aucuparia) related to the apple, butwith pinnate leaves and flat corymbs of small white flowers followedby little bright red berries. Called also roan tree, and mountainash. The name is also applied to two American trees of similar habit(Pyrus Americana, and P. sambucifolia).
raptores: Same as Accipitres. Called also Raptatores.
retransform: To transform anew or back.-- Re`trans*for*ma"tion, n.
roundridge: To form into round ridges by plowing. B. Edwards.
relegation: The act of relegating, or the state of being relegated;removal; banishment; exile.
rotal: Relating to wheels or to rotary motion; rotary. [R.]
respirable: Suitable for being breathed; adapted for respiration.-- Re*spir"a*ble*ness, n.
reviviscent: Able or disposed to revive; reviving. E. Darwin.
research: Diligent inquiry or examination in seeking facts or principles;laborius or continued search after truth; as, researches of humanwisdom.The dearest interests of parties have frequently been staked on theresults of the researches of antiquaries. Macaulay.
regularity: The condition or quality of being regular; as, regularity ofoutline; the regularity of motion.
rowed: Formed into a row, or rows; having a row, or rows; as, atwelve-rowed ear of corn.
rhabdocoelous: Of or pertaining to the Rhabdocoela.
revolutionary: Of or pertaining to a revolution in government; tending to, orpromoting, revolution; as, revolutionary war; revolutionary measures;revolutionary agitators.
remissible: Capable of being remitted or forgiven. Feltham.
rooftree: The beam in the angle of a roof; hence, the roof itself.Now for me the woods may wither, now for me the rooftree fall.Tennyson.
resultate: A result. [Obs.] "The resultate of their counsil." BAcon.
rusma: A depilatory made of orpiment and quicklime, and used by theTurks. See Rhusma.
rampire: A rampart. [Archaic]The Trojans round the place a rampire cast. Dryden.
respersion: The act of sprinkling or scattering. [Obs.]
rosedrop: A ruddy eruption upon the nose caused by drinking ardentspirits; a grog blossom.
resurrectionist: One who steals bodies from the grave, as for dissection.[Slang]
rubiretin: One of the red dye products extracted from madder root, andprobably identical with ruberythrinic acid.
revitalize: To restore vitality to; to bring back to life. L. S. Beale.
retard: To stay back. [Obs.] Sir. T. Browne.
restaurateur: The keeper of an eathing house or a restaurant.
revers: A part turned or folded back so as to show the inside, or apiece put on in imitation of such a part, as the lapel of a coat.
replacement: The removal of an edge or an angle by one or more planes.
rot: A disease or decay in fruits, leaves, or wood, supposed to becaused by minute fungi. See Bitter rot, Black rot, etc., below.
rhyparography: In ancient art, the painting of genre or still-life pictures.
repossess: To possess again; as, to repossess the land. Pope. To repossessone's self of (something), to acquire again (something lost).
ribaldry: The talk of a ribald; low, vulgar language; indecency;obscenity; lewdness; -- now chiefly applied to indecent language, butformerly, as by Chaucer, also to indecent acts or conduct.The ribaldry of his conversation moved Macaulay.
reannex: To annex again or anew; to reunite. "To reannex that duchy."Bacon.
rough-footed: Feather-footed; as, a rough-footed dove. [R.] Sherwood.
rejectamenta: Things thrown out or away; especially, things excreted by aliving organism. J. Fleming.
repealer: One who repeals; one who seeks a repeal; specifically, anadvocate for the repeal of the Articles of Union between GreatBritain and Ireland.
represent: To form or image again in consciousness, as an object ofcognition or apprehension (something which was originally apprehendedby direct presentation). See Presentative,3.The general capability of knowledge necessarily requires that,besides the power of evoking out of unconsciousness one portion ofour retained knowledge in preference to another, we posses thefaculty of representing in consciousness what is thus evoked . . .This representative Faculty is Imagination or Phantasy. Sir. W.Hamilton.
rejoindure: Act of joining again. [Obs.] "Beguiles our lips of allrejoindure" (i.e., kisses). Shak.
recluseness: Quality or state of being recluse.
ramed: Having the frames, stem, and sternpost adjusted; -- said of aship on the stocks.
ripieno: Filling up; supplementary; supernumerary; -- a term applied tothose instruments which only swell the mass or tutti of an orchestra,but are not obbligato.
ruptuary: One not of noble blood; a plebeian; a roturier. [R.]The exclusion of the French ruptuaries ("roturiers," for history mustfind a word for this class when it speaks of other nations) from theorder of nobility. Chenevix.
resinaceous: Having the quality of resin; resinous.
repand: Having a slightly undulating margin; -- said of leaves.
russian church: The established church of the Russian empire. It forms aportion, by far the largest, of the Eastern Church and is governed bythe Holy Synod. The czar is the head of the church, but he has neverclaimed the right of deciding questions of theology and dogma.
romaic: Of or relating to modern Greece, and especially to itslanguage.-- n.
righteous: Doing, or according with, that which is right; yielding to alltheir due; just; equitable; especially, free from wrong, guilt, orsin; holy; as, a righteous man or act; a righteous retribution.Fearless in his righteous cause. Milton.
roundtop: A top; a platform at a masthead; -- so called because formerlyround in shape.
rush: A name given to many aquatic or marsh-growing endogenous plantswith soft, slender stems, as the species of Juncus and Scirpus.
recussion: The act of beating or striking back.
rhinolophid: Any species of the genus Rhinilophus, or family Rhinolophidæ,having a horseshoe-shaped nasal crest; a horseshoe bat.
rigadoon: A gay, lively dance for one couple, -- said to have beenborrowed from Provence in France. W. Irving.Whose dancing dogs in rigadoons excel. Wolcott.
radiant engine: A semiradial engine. See Radial engine, above.
reset: To set again; as, to reset type; to reset copy; to reset adiamond.
ramberge: Formerly, a kind of large war galley.
rash: A fine eruption or efflorescence on the body, with little or noelevation. Canker rash. See in the Vocabulary.-- Nettle rash. See Urticaria.-- Rose rash. See Roseola.-- Tooth rash. See Red-gum.
ridable: Suitable for riding; as, a ridable horse; a ridable road.
rentable: Capable of being rented, or suitable for renting.
rubric: That part of any work in the early manuscripts and typographywhich was colored red, to distinguish it from other portions. Hence,specifically:(a) A titlepage, or part of it, especially that giving the date andplace of printing; also, the initial letters, etc., when printed inred.(b) (Law books) The title of a statute; -- so called as beinganciently written in red letters. Bell.(c) (Liturgies) The directions and rules for the conduct of service,formerly written or printed in red; hence, also, an ecclesiastical orepiscopal injunction; -- usually in the plural.All the clergy in England solemnly pledge themselves to observe therubrics. Hook.
ruralness: The quality or state of being rural.
rindle: A small water course or gutter. Ash.
remonstrate: To point out; to show clearly; to make plain or manifest;hence, to prove; to demonstrate. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.I will remonstrate to you the third door. B. Jonson.
readjournment: The act of readjourning; a second or repeated adjournment.
railleur: A banterer; a jester; a mocker. [R.] Wycherley.
recreant: One who yields in combat, and begs for mercy; a mean-spirited,cowardly wretch. Blackstone.You are all recreants and dastards! Shak.
rotella: Any one of numerous species of small, polished, brightcoloredgastropods of the genus Rotella, native of tropical seas.
rattan: One of the long slender flexible stems of several species ofpalms of the genus Calamus, mostly East Indian, though some areAfrican and Australian. They are exceedingly tough, and are used forwalking sticks, wickerwork, chairs and seats of chairs, cords andcordage, and many other purposes.
russophobia: Morbid dread of Russia or of Russian influence.
redia: A kind of larva, or nurse, which is prroduced within thesporocyst of certain trematodes by asexual generation. It in turnproduces, in the same way, either another generation of rediæ, orelse cercariæ within its own body. Called also proscolex, and nurse.See Illustration in Appendix.
revengement: Revenge. [Obs.]He 'll breed revengement and a scourge for me. Shak.
resumptive: Taking back; resuming, or tending toward resumption; as,resumptive measures.
ringbolt: An eyebolt having a ring through the eye.
rencounter: To meet unexpectedly; to encounter in a hostile manner; to comein collision; to skirmish.
revilement: The act of reviling; also, contemptuous language; reproach;abuse. Spenser.
redargue: To disprove; to refute; toconfute; to reprove; to convict.[Archaic]How shall I . . . suffer that God should redargue me at doomsday, andthe angels reproach my lukewarmness Jer. Taylor.Now this objection to the immediate cognition of external objectshas, as far as I know, been redargued in three different ways. Sir W.Hamilton.
rockwork: Stonework in which the surface is left broken and rough.
rattler: One who, or that which, rattles.
rebellow: To bellow again; to repeat or echo a bellow.The cave rebellowed, and the temple shook. Dryden.
riprap: A foundation or sustaining wall of stones thrown togetherwithout order, as in deep water or on a soft bottom.
resolvability: The quality or condition of being resolvable; resolvableness.
reptile: An animal that crawls, or moves on its belly, as snakes,, or bymeans of small, short legs, as lizards, and the like.An inadvertent step may crush the snail That crawls at evening in thepublic path; But he that has humanity, forewarned, Will tread aside,and let the reptile live. Cowper.
renal-portal: Both renal and portal. See Portal.
repent: Prostrate and rooting; -- said of stems. Gray.
reviling: Reproach; abuse; vilification.Neither be ye afraid of their revilings. Isa. li. 7.
reimpression: A second or repeated impression; a reprint.
reimportation: The act of reimporting; also, that which is reimported.
ripple: An implement, with teeth like those of a comb, for removing theseeds and seed vessels from flax, broom corn, etc.
radiolarian: Of or pertaining to the Radiolaria.-- n.
raciness: The quality of being racy; peculiar and piquant flavor.The general characteristics of his [Cobbett's] style wereperspicuity, unequaled and inimitable; . . . a purity always simple,and raciness often elegant. London Times.
red-riband: The European red band fish, or fireflame. See Rend fish.
rat-tailed: Having a long, tapering tail like that of a rat. Rat-tailedlarva (Zoöl.), the larva of a fly of the genus Eristalis. SeeEristalis.-- Rat-tailed serpent (Zoöl.), the fer-de-lance.-- Rat-tailed shrew (Zoöl.), the musk shrew.
raffish: Resembling, or having the character of, raff, or a raff;worthless; low.A sad, raffish, disreputable character. Thackeray.
rapid: The part of a river where the current moves with greatswiftness, but without actual waterfall or cascade; -- usually in theplural; as, the Lachine rapids in the St. Lawrence.Row, brothers, row the stream runs fast, The rapids are near, and thedaylight's past. Moore.
ream: Cream; also, the cream or froth on ale. [Scot.]
rout: To roar; to bellow; to snort; to snore loudly. [Obs. or Scot.]Chaucer.
ready: A word of command, or a position, in the manual of arms, atwhich the piece is cocked and held in position to execute promptlythe next command, which is, aim. All ready, ready in everyparticular; wholly equipped or prepared. "[I] am all redy at yourhest." Chaucer.-- Ready money, means of immediate payment; cash. "'Tis all theready money fate can give." Cowley.-- Ready reckoner, a book of tables for facilitating computations,as of interest, prices, etc.-- To make ready, to make preparation; to get in readiness.
retrusion: The act of retruding, or the state of being retruded.In virtue of an endless remotion or retrusion of the constituentcause. Coleridge.
rechabite: One of the descendants of Jonadab, the son of Rechab, all ofwhom by his injunction abstained from the use of intoxicating drinksand even from planting the vine. Jer. xxxv. 2-19. Also, in moderntimes, a member of a certain society of abstainers from alcoholicliquors.
resurvey: To survey again or anew; to review. Shak.
recarnify: To convert again into flesh. [Obs.] Howell.
revoluble: Capable of revolving; rotatory; revolving. [Obs.]Us, then, to whom the thrice three year Hath filled his revoluble orbsince our arrival here, I blame not. Chapman.
